awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Handheld Ballistics Imaging Device
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project supports law enforcement in solving crimes committed with firearms. In 2020, gun crime in the U.S. reached an all-time high with over 300,000 crimes committed and 40,000 people killed by a firearm, resulting in a $280 billion impact on the economy. There are approximately 800,000 law enforcement officers and 18,000 agencies in the U.S., and many of them have little to no access to forensics technology due to its cost and complexity. The total addressable market for this technology is estimated at $360 million per year in the U.S. This project advances hardware and software for next-generation portable ballistic devices, matching a spent shell casing to the weapon that fired it.  

The intellectual merit of this project is to advance the collection and analysis of forensic ballistics data. This project will develop: (1) a ruggedized scanner to allow detailed, microscopic, three-dimensional imagery to be captured in the field; (2) an optical system that addresses the inherent difficulties and scattering challenges of scanning metals; (3) a user interface to upload images and receive leads, while preserving chain of custody and security; and (4) a cloud-based analytical system capable of comparing digitized/pixelated imagery to provide a “match” back to investigators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

   In this NSF SBIR Grant Phase I initiative, iBallistix continued prototyping the portable ballistics imaging device described in our grant proposal, which utilizes the optics of an iPhone in conjunction with an internal macro-lens to image expended bullet cartridge (or “shell casing”) headstamps. We developed algorithms to process and compare surface features and created user-facing and back-end software to support the comparison experience. iBallistix moved swiftly from a basic proof-of-concept prototype intended for a lab setting to a customer-ready prototype with enough functionality and robustness to kick off field trials with multiple police agencies.

   iBallistix has shown that our patented ShotOptix scanner can be used to accurately match shell casings by employing computer vision and artificial intelligence algorithms to help automate the process. In so doing, we provide a field-deployable means to electronically transmit shell casing scans to the cloud for automated processing. Our system, in turn, passes these on to a firearm and toolmark examiner for further virtual inspection and association without the need to have physical evidence in hand. This methodology contrasts how information is passed today, where physical evidence must be transferred before any data processing can begin.

Intellectual Merit

   The principal discipline of this project - forensic ballistics analysis - has traditionally relied upon expensive and large laboratory equipment that is inaccessible to most agencies. Our technology democratizes forensic ballistic evidence collection and shell casing comparison technology for Law Enforcement. It is the first fully portable handheld forensic ballistics scanner. Furthermore, it is the first scanner that can be used by non-technical law enforcement officers in the field to capture evidence while at the crime scene and transmit this evidence directly to a firearm and toolmark examiner, thereby accelerating data processing. It provides the capability for officers to examine in near real time all forensic ballistic evidence within a given vicinity and view patterns of matching crime activity. Empowering street COPS to play a more active role in an investigation and take a more hands-on role in the case encourages deeper buy-in and frees the evidence collection personnel to work on other items such as DNA, etc.

   Current systems for collecting and analyzing forensic evidence associated with firearm-related crimes and injuries lack portability and can be prohibitively slow. Further, shell casing imaging technology and 3D scanning methodology, even extremely expensive high-precision confocal microscopes, structured light laser scanners, and other forensic inspection systems cannot easily image the metallic surfaces of shell casings because of their highly faceted, specular, non-Lambertian properties. By contrast, the iBallistix ShotOptix scanner is a small and rugged handheld unit that can be used in the field to scan a variety of different types of shell casings, despite their challenging surface properties.

Broader Impacts

   The United States is suffering from a firearms violence epidemic that is ravaging cities, neighborhoods, and families. Every day in America over 300 people are shot with 40,000+ deaths annually according to Pew Research and Brady United. Worse yet, the leading cause of death among children in the US is from firearms violence. This problem drains our spirit as a nation as well as a significant portion of our national wealth, with costs reaching some $557 billion per year (or 2.6% of GDP) according to Harvard Medical School researchers. This violence disproportionately affects the black community.

   iBallistix’ aim is to enable police agencies to deploy a device in the field that officers can use to help them rapidly generate leads in crimes involving gun violence. The information provided by our system is intended to complement other investigative avenues that police use to solve crimes and to build case momentum. iBallistix technology empowers technical and non-technical personnel, alike, to employ sophisticated forensic ballistic techniques in the field and accelerate the pace at which evidence is examined and processed and from which leads are generated. It will help close criminal investigations more quickly, potentially enhancing the productivity of everyone involved, and make the streets safer.

   iBallistix intends to advance its research and development to the point where it can begin early commercialization of the first truly portable, handheld ballistics imaging device. This will be the fastest ballistic forensics lead-generation system in the world. Pricing will be significantly less than current tools, making it accessible to all. Target markets include local, state, and federal law enforcement. Through our R&D, iBallistix addresses criterion with respect to the American Innovation and Competitiveness Act (P.L. 114-329, Section 102) Broader Impacts Review Criterion in the category of Advancing of the health and welfare of the American public.
